sub_title: PhD Candidate in Benefit Transfers for Patient-Centred Drug Development
summary: I'm a PhD candidate at the Health Technology and Services Research section at the University of Twente. My research interests include (clinical) prediction models, meta-analyses, quantitative preference elicitation techniques, and clinical decision-making support.

awards.title: Twente Graduate School Award Finalist 2022
awards.description: The faculty board of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science (EEMCS) nominated me to compete in the finals of the Twente Graduate School grant competition. In total, five candidates were selected across the entire university (one from each faculty), to compete for a fully-funded PhD position for 4 years. I proudly represented the EEMCS faculty with my research proposal: "Dynamic Data- and Expert-Driven Models: Supporting Clinical Decision-Making in Geriatric Trauma Surgery and Oncology".
awards.issuer: Twente Graduate School, University of Twente

awards.title: Bright IDEa Concept Development Award
awards.description:
We won the Bright IDEa contest in which 17 university student teams participated. The challenge revolved around the question of how students can become catalysts of local innovation in Enschede's neighborhoods. Our solution is the Enschede Innovation Toolbox. It makes the abstract design process easier to grasp by representing it as a tangible and systematic roadmap, which can be followed easily by both multidisciplinary student teams and inhabitants of the city of Enschede. While aiming to establish connections between organizations, students, and inhabitants, we use local knowledge to tailor the design process to Enschede itself. By doing so, it supports students in becoming catalysts of innovation in Enschede.

https://www.enschedelab.nl/bright-idea-studentencontest-levert-handenvol-mooie-concepten-op/

https://www.utwente.nl/en/designlab/news/2020/7/694243/winners-design-contest-put-master-inserts-theory-into-practice

Contributors: Sefora Tunc and Nora Tunc

awards.title: Creative Technology Graduation Project Award
awards.description: I won the annual Creative Technology Graduation Project Award with my thesis: Empathic Techniques for Co-Design with Spinal Muscular Atrophy Type II. I developed a novel scenario-based design framework based on empathy, value-sensitive design, and subjunctivizing transformation analysis. I am one of the first people to conduct a co-design study with a member from the SMA type II population; to the best of my knowledge, no literature was available at the time. Additionally, I conducted research on making complex design tasks more accessible to users, by studying the underlying mechanisms of associative and creative thinking.

awards.title: Innovation and Entrepreneurship Award
awards.description:
We won the award for the best project in the Innovation and Entrepreneurship module of the Creative Technology bachelor's program, which revolves around the Lean Startup Methodology, supported by courses on opportunity recognition, industry and competitor analyses, innovation management, technological mediation theory, and nudging in business practice.

For the project, a business plan for a smart medication manager had been developed. The system reduces medication associated stress and risks amongst elderly as it seamlessly and conveniently integrates in their daily lives without external device usage.

Contributors: Kevin Folkertsma, Max Pijnappel, Bart Sprenkels, and Koen Vogel

awards.title: Human-Computer Interaction Award: Most Added Value
awards.description:
We won the award for the best HCI project in the category: Most Added Value. This award was granted during the Intelligent Interaction Design module of the Creative Technology bachelor's program, which revolves around user experience, grounded design decisions, evaluations of interactive systems, and artificial intelligence. For the HCI project, the interactive system SopraNOsolo has been developed. SopraNOsolo is an asymmetrical game designed for siblings of which one is neurotypical and the other has social and collaborative deficiencies caused by an autism spectrum syndrome. The learning goal is to enhance social and communicative behavior.  One of the players has to traverse a platform, while the other player cannot see what is happening in the game. The blinded player has to arrange the music notes in between the platforms to build bridges which can be crossed. The correct sequence of notes will result in hearing a familiar melody after stepping on top of them. Through communication and cooperation, the two players can complete the level together.

The design decisions have been based on various interviews with experts and stakeholders, low fidelity prototype confrontations, and heuristic evaluations.

Contributors: Kevin Folkertsma, Marloes ten Hage, Ikmareka Hunt, and Maaike Keurhorst

projects.title: The Sensitivity of Neuronal Activation Towards Deep Brain Stimulation Electrode Orientations in Anisotropic Brain Tissue
projects.description: The electrode placement in the subthalamic nucleus is pivotal to the efficacy of deep brain stimulation (DBS) as a treatment for the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. Hence, the objective of this study was to research the stimulation effect of electrode orientations during monopolar DBS. Previous studies have assumed that the anisotropy of white matter could be neglected in brain tissue models to estimate the influence of DBS. The current study inspected whether this simplification was justifiable, by examining the sensitivity of DBS to electrode angles in both isotropic and anisotropic brain tissue models. The results showed that the volume of tissue activated (VTA) in the isotropic model showed little variability throughout all electrode rotations from 0-90°. Conversely, the activations in the anistropic model showed greater selectivity to the electrode angles, with a lower overall VTA. Hence, simplifying the conductive properties of brain tissue by neglecting the anisotropy of white matter could overestimate the VTA of DBS.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate in Benefit Transfers for Patient-Centred Drug Development

projects.title: Computational Study of Stimulus-Driven Absence Seizure Abatement
projects.description:
We implemented the neural field model as described by Taylor et al. [1] to study the dynamics of absence epilepsy. The published deterministic model [2] was used as a starting point. All other numerical algorithms that led to a reproduction of the results of [1] were developed by ourselves. This includes constructing the bifurcation diagram, simulating the stochastic (bistable) model, and determining the success rates of neurostimulation along various timestamps in an epileptic spike-wave discharge. To further build upon the results of Taylor et al., we quantified the intercycle variability of successful absence seizure abatement. By doing so, we determined the optimal timing for neurostimulation with the highest success rate.

[1] Taylor PN, Wang Y, Marc G, Justin D, Friederike M, Ulrich S, et al.  A computational study of stimulus driven epileptic seizure abatement. PLoS ONE. 2014 12;9(12):e114316. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0114316

[2] Wang  Y.  Amari  Neural  Field  model. Available  from: https://senselab.med.yale.edu/modeldb/showModel.cshtml?model=168856&file=/TaylorWangetal2014/#tabs-1

profile_positions.description: As a PhD candidate at the Health Technology and Services Research section, I conduct research on statistical models for benefit transfers of quantitative patient preference information. In collaboration with Novartis, I am developing novel meta-regression techniques to extrapolate benefit-risk trade-offs between patient-relevant endpoints across disease indications and countries. We will study the factors underlying preference heterogeneity to perform methodologically sound benefit transfers, to further support patient-centred medical product development.
profile_positions.title: PHD Candidate

profile_positions.description: I conducted research on value sensitive design of eHealth services in rehabilitation care. I developed a framework for collecting, analysing, and mapping important personal values along the patient journey, to better support patients throughout their care delivery. My research was rewarded with a 9/10.
profile_positions.title: eHealth Research Intern
